author: By Corey Kilgannon, Justin Morris and Sean Piccoli
title: Early Lines and Free Doughnuts: Legal Marijuana Sales Begin in New Jersey
description: Recreational cannabis customers in the state can now legally buy up to an ounce of marijuana per sale.
content: The customers began lining up before dawn at Rise Paterson, a marijuana dispensary in New Jersey that was welcoming customers with free doughnuts and reggaeton blaring from loudspeakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: A Muslim dating site loses a trademark case against an industry giant.
description: A London court ruled that Muzmatch, a start-up, had infringed on the trademarks of Match Group, the owner of Tinder.
content: A Muslim dating and marriage app, Muzmatch, lost a legal battle on Wednesday against the owners of Tinder, one of the world’s most popular dating apps, after a British court ruled that the start-up had infringed on the multibillion-dollar company’s trademarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth and Julie Bloom
title: Postcards From the Biennale
description: His paintings travel, but Ha Chong-hyun stays in Korea; Anselm Kiefer melds art and sculpture at the Doges Palace.
content: VENICE — After a delay, this city is once again filled with the art class — the pavilions are full, and the parties are thrumming. But the coronavirus is still creating problems. Ha Chong-hyun, a revered Korean artist and exponent of Dansaekhwa or monochrome (single-color) painting, 86, was set to toast the opening of a survey of his work this week at the Palazzetto Tito, but both he and his wife, Park Mi-ja, tested positive and stayed home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Cericola
title: The Best Smart-Home Devices for Aging in Place Comfortably
description: It may all sound terrifyingly high-tech, but take comfort: If you can use a smartphone app, you can use any of these modern tools.
content: As we get older, we tend to accumulate more stuff that we have to keep track of — appointments, visitors, coffee tables we keep bumping into. Meanwhile, routine things like late-night bathroom trips can start to feel a bit more hazardous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: With Elon Musk, You Can’t Spell “Funding Secured” Without “Fun”
description: The rocket man shored up $46.5 billion for his Twitter bid, pushing the drama toward its third week.
content: Weed joke notwithstanding, Elon Musk’s $54.20 “best and final offer” for Twitter shares in his hostile takeover bid was never likely to be either final or best. And so the noisy scrum Musk created with his surprise offer for the social media company moved to the obvious and much quieter place of behind-the-scenes financing and deal making. Quieter, perhaps, but still not boring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Younger Than It Looks, but No More Diverse: France’s Top Theater Prize
description: At the Molières, France’s equivalent of the Tony Awards, commercial and publicly funded productions seem to inhabit different worlds.
content: PARIS — Four hundred years after his birth, the playwright Molière is being feted in France this year, and the theater awards that bear his name couldn’t pass up the chance to participate. The Molières, France’s equivalent of the Tony Awards, have jokingly renamed their yearly bash — set for May 30 — the 400th ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Will Smith, Before the Slap
description: Plenty has been said about Oscars night. But what about the rapper-turned-actor’s remarkable journey up to that point?
content: Will Smith’s outburst at the Oscars last month derailed the broadcast, his coronation as best actor later that night and the public good-guy image he’d carefully cultivated for several decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Florida Wedding Guests Are Sickened by Marijuana in Food, Police Say
description: The bride and the wedding caterer have been charged with tampering with food and delivering marijuana, according to the authorities in Seminole County.
content: Soon after a meal of meatballs, bread, tortellini and Caesar salad, the guests at the wedding of Andrew and Danya Svoboda began to feel strange, according to the authorities in Seminole County, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: There’s Muscle Memory Behind Jamie Nares’s Brushstrokes
description: For decades, the artist has created paintings in a single sweep.
content: In 1992, I started making paintings with one brushstroke. It seemed like there was enough going on within a single brushstroke to keep me interested. I wanted it to look blown on, like the pigment used for those hands in cave drawings. It was all about speed, touch, timing. It’s difficult to be precise. When I first started doing these one-brushstroke paintings, if I didn’t like what I’d done, I’d get down on my hands and knees with a can of mineral spirits and a bunch of rags and wipe it off. By the time I’d finished that, I’d lost the kind of muscle memory of what I was trying to do. And it’s very important to the paintings that they be a transference of some accumulation of muscle memories from the body to the brush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: The Dark Side of Tea-Making
description: Judy I. Lin’s debut fantasy novel for young adults is “steeped” in the ancient traditions of her native Taiwan.
content: When Judy I. Lin was growing up — first in her native Taiwan, then in Alberta, Canada, where she moved at the age of 8 and lives today — she couldn’t find many fantasy books featuring Asian characters, let alone Taiwanese ones. So, in 2018, she decided to write her own, for her young daughter to read one day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Ivo van Hove on His Famously Short Rehearsal Times
description: Since his first production a quarter-century ago, the director has honed a process defined by tight schedules and bold, decisive changes.
content: I was at New York Theatre Workshop 25 years ago with my first production: Eugene O’Neill’s “More Stately Mansions” (1964). Since then, people have called me “the man you love to hate or hate to love” — a badge of honor, as far as I’m concerned. Later, I moved on to Broadway, but I kept returning to NYTW. Its rehearsal space is upstairs on the third floor, and I originally disliked it because it feels like a big living room, but eventually I fell for it. I’ve now done eight productions here, the last of which was “Lazarus” in 2015 with David Bowie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moira Weigel
title: What You Don’t Know About Amazon
description: The company’s rewiring of retail puts customers at risk.
content: When Carey Gartner ordered a TV remote on Amazon in 2017, it arrived promptly at his home in Texas, most likely in one of those standard brown boxes with the company’s logo: an arrow tilting up in a half-smile. A year later, the battery cover popped off the remote, exposing a lithium battery, and Gartner’s 19-month-old swallowed it, severely burning and permanently damaging her esophagus, according to allegations in a court filing. His wife, Morgan McMillan, sued Amazon on their daughter’s behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Dozens of Bald Eagles Have Died From Bird Flu
description: The H5N1 strain of avian influenza is spreading among many raptors and wild birds, including the national bird.
content: With millions of chickens on commercial poultry farms sickened and dying from a highly virulent strain of avian flu in recent months, it might have escaped notice that some of the nation’s most stunning wild birds have also been felled by the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy and Adrian J. Rivera
title: ‘I Don’t Think It’s Going to Stop in Ukraine’: 10 Americans on Putin’s War
description: In Times Opinion’s latest focus group, 10 Americans talked about Vladimir Putin, Volodymyr Zelensky and where the war in Ukraine goes from here.
content: The conventional wisdom is that Americans, scarred by the country’s involvement in wars for the last two decades, are by and large done with all that. When Russia invaded Ukraine, there was never a question of whether President Biden would send in U.S. troops to assist the Ukrainians. This wasn’t just because of a war-weary public: Pitting two nuclear powers against each other was incomprehensible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: In This ‘Billy the Kid,’ the Wounds Are Those You Cannot See
description: In a new Epix drama starring Tom Blyth and Eileen O’Higgins, the legendary 19th-century gunslinger and killer gets a modern origin story.
content: Billy the Kid, the 19th-century gunfighter memorialized through more than 140 years of pop culture, carries with him countless myths and renditions, a different Billy for each generation’s needs — the pariah, the victim, the Everyman.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: While living in Tel Aviv as a member of Israel’s renowned Batsheva Dance Company, the mesmerizing performer Shamel Pitts began making his own work, including a solo called “Black Box — Little Black Book of RED.” The first part of what would become Pitts’s three-part “Black Series,” the piece examined his personal journey and Black identity through his signature strong, silky movement and powerful poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Next It Bag?
description: Kerby Jean-Raymond of Pyer Moss gets into the accessories game.
content: When Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder of Pyer Moss, was growing up the East Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn, he worked after school at a sneaker store called Ragga Muffin, where most everyone he knew got their kicks. For four years, from age 13 to 17, he would wander home from the store past a billboard that dominated Flatbush Avenue, advertising such services as divorce help and class-action lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoey Poll
title: For Virginie Viard, Inspiration Comes During Walks by the Seine
description: Chanel’s creative director seeks out Paris’s quieter corners to clear her head.
content: I cross the Seine most days — it gives me a breath of fresh air, a sense of momentum. It’s like a springboard. And it makes me think of so many different photographs of Paris, showing all sorts of time periods and atmospheres. When I worked with my former boss, Karl Lagerfeld, we would take lots of pictures on the quays. Whenever he didn’t know where to go, we went down to the river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: A Versatile Masala for Almost Any Frozen Vegetable
description: Okra, edamame, butternut squash, cauliflower, corn — they all work in this recipe.
content: Okra is glorious in all its forms — pickled, roasted, stewed, grilled — but I have a soft spot for Zainab Shah’s bhindi masala, in which it’s sautéed and dressed in a spicy tomato sauce. It reminds me so much of the weeknight meals I had growing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The U.S. will outfit five artillery battalions for Ukraine and provide new drones that explode on impact.
description: The Biden administration is sending dozens of howitzers and 120 drones in the latest $800 million package of military aid.
content: The Pentagon is sending an additional $800 million in defense aid to Ukraine that effectively will create five new Ukrainian artillery battalions, and includes more than 120 new drones built specifically for use by Ukraine’s forces. Officials made the announcement in a statement sent to reporters Thursday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Guadagnino
title: When Their Show Was Postponed, a Playwright and Cast Turned to Poetry
description: Two years ago, on what was meant to be opening night of “The Vagrant Trilogy,” Mona Mansour hosted the first of many readings with her colleagues.
content: My show “The Vagrant Trilogy” is a conditional trilogy — a bit like the movie “Sliding Doors” (1998). In the first play, a young man and his wife travel from Palestine to London for a conference. Then the 1967 Arab-Israeli war breaks out, and they have to decide what to do. What follows are two different versions of what happens. The play’s about what’s lost when you leave and the idea that, once you do, you’re never really going to be of the place you came from — or the one you’ve gone to. The production was meant to be put on at the Public Theater in New York in the spring of 2020, but Covid-19 intervened. We left the theater and our stuff, thinking, like so many others, that we’d be back soon. It was an odd thing to happen in the middle of a show about displaced people. By no means am I comparing what we went through to the fate of refugees, but it gave us a taste of that kind of stasis and lack of agency, that Chekhovian sort of waiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a seven-bedroom house in Locust Valley, N.Y., and a four-bedroom house in Cranbury, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: How James Whiteside Becomes His Drag Queen Alter Ego
description: As Ühu Betch, the ballet dancer is able to express himself in a different way, with room for mistakes.
content: My office desk does double duty as a vanity. It sits under a window that looks out onto a street with lots of brownstones — I’ve been here in Park Slope since August 2020, when the apartment was passed on to me by a friend of a friend who was moving to the countryside. The natural light is amazing, perfect for getting into drag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colleen Creamer
title: In Nashville, Boisterous Fun and Decadent Eating
description: With the opening of a big African American music museum, new retro bowling halls and a ramped-up food scene, Nashville just kept on growing over the last two years. A visitors’ guide.
content: As the weather warms, travelers anxious to get back to honky-tonkin’ in Nashville can expect not only to find things much as they were prepandemic — Tootsies Orchid Lounge, Legends Corner and Robert’s Western World are still cranking out boisterous fun along Lower Broadway — but also a vertiginous number of new restaurants, hotels and music venues. They will also find one of the most impactful music museums to open anywhere in decades: the National Museum of African American Music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Charlotte’ Review: An Artist’s Brief Life
description: This animated biopic about the German Jewish painter Charlotte Salomon takes faithful inspiration from her life. What if it had taken more energy from her art?
content: In the animated biopic “Charlotte,” about the German Jewish painter Charlotte Salomon, the film’s most eloquent moment may be its last. Concluding on an image of the French Riviera as the sounds of a Nazi roundup can be heard, the directors Éric Warin and Tahir Rana come closest to capturing Salomon’s brief life with its tensions between the creative and the nihilistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Air Travel Is Back. Now the Airlines Have to Keep Up.
description: American, United and Delta are gearing up for a flood of bookings. But the industry faces constraints in taking full advantage of the demand.
content: Air travel is back. Can the industry keep up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Sameer Yasir
title: Why Are Kangaroos Turning Up in India?
description: The animals are the latest exotic fauna to be smuggled into the country, possibly to be used as pets. Draft legislation would close loopholes in the roaring wildlife trade.
content: On the edges of forests in eastern India, people have been stumbling upon hungry, scared marsupials that they do not recognize. The animals are kangaroos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What’s the Big Deal About a Woman Being Bald?
description: Hair is a potent symbol of self, of gender, of subversion. To renounce it can be just as powerful.
content: In all the talk of “the slap” that has gone on since the Oscars; in all the soul-searching prompted by that break from the norm, its aftermath and what it could mean not just for the Smiths or the Academy but for comedy, culture and gender writ large; in all the important medical discussions it engendered of alopecia, not to mention the complex role hair has played in Black history — there has been one constant underlying it all: the powerful symbolism of the bald female head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara
title: Near Milan, Cassina’s Art Director Digs Through the Brand’s Archives
description: Patricia Urquiola finds energy deep inside company headquarters, via old comic strips and revolutionary original works.
content: Cassina has manufactured furniture since 1927 and maintains an archive of roughly 600 pieces, some of which are still being produced. But, from the beginning, it’s also been important to the company to make new things, to be open to collaborating with and editing the contemporary masters of design. It’s this idea of creating a cultural continuum that interests me, and to which I’m honored to contribute as Cassina’s art director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Karen Zraick and Todd Heisler
title: Survivors of Deadly Bronx Fire Feel Betrayed: ‘Where Is My City?’
description: Nearly four months after a fire tore through a Bronx building, killing 17 people, its residents say New York City has yet to disburse millions in aid.
content: Some mornings, Nikki Campbell finds herself staring at the ceiling for a good half-hour. Inside her head, she sees her teenage children jumping up and down at the windows of their apartment, screaming as flames gather around them, melting walls so quickly that the paint breaks out in bubbles and black smoke fills the hallways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Disney vs. Florida
description: A debate over taxes is rapidly unraveling Florida’s long relationship with Disney, with broader implications for corporate America.
content: Yesterday, the Florida Senate voted to revoke special benefits that, since the 1960s, have given Disney the ability to essentially self-govern a vast area around its Disney World theme park and issue tax-free municipal bonds. The state’s House, which like its Senate is led by Republicans, is expected to vote for the measure today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Jay Wright, Hall of Fame Villanova Basketball Coach, Retires
description: A head coach since 1994, Wright, 60, had a .695 career winning percentage across tenures at Hofstra and Villanova. His 21-season career at Villanova included national titles in 2016 and 2018.
content: Jay Wright’s storied run at Villanova has come to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore and Giovanni Russonello
title: The Multifaceted Mingus
description: On the bassist and bandleader’s centennial, 10 jazz musicians discuss his achievements and complexities and pick out a pivotal track from his repertoire.
content: Charles Mingus was everything all at once: jazz, folk, dance, theater, label owner, brave Black man. In an era where the wrong opinions could get him killed or, at the very least, exiled from the music business, he expressed himself boldly, and exorcised strong emotions through the strings of his upright bass. His playing style was fierce, almost violent, as if the trauma of American racism was coming through it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
title: Next Phase of War Will Be Pivotal for Russia and Ukraine, U.S. Says
description: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior Biden administration officials say they believe that the next four weeks will shape the eventual outcome of Russia’s war in Ukraine, with long-lasting ramifications that will influence the drawing of the map of Europe for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: F.B.I. Issues Navajo Language Alert for Unsolved Homicide
description: In an unusual step, the mother of Lee Michael Pahe, who was found dead in July 2021, made a plea on the radio in her language, seeking information about her son’s death.
content: The F.B.I. started airing a radio ad last week seeking information about the fatal shooting of a man in Naschitti, N.M., within the Navajo Nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Berkvist
title: Robert Morse, Impish Tony-Winning Comedy Star, Is Dead at 90
description: He dazzled as a charming corporate schemer in “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.” His later triumphs included a memorable role on “Mad Men.”
content: Robert Morse, whose impish, gaptoothed grin and expert comic timing made him a Tony-winning Broadway star as a charming corporate schemer in the 1961 musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” who later won another Tony for his eerily lifelike portrait of the writer Truman Capote in “Tru,” and who capped his long career with a triumphant return to the corporate world on the television series “Mad Men,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Emily Cochrane
title: Plane Carrying Army Parachutists Briefly Alarms Capitol
description: After the Capitol was evacuated, Nancy Pelosi lashed out at the F.A.A. for its “apparent failure to notify Capitol Police of the preplanned flyover.”
content: WASHINGTON — A plane carrying members of the Army’s Golden Knights parachute team was taking part in a celebration of the armed forces at Nationals Park on Wednesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Wang
title: Alexander Wang Returns to the Runway
description: The designer attempted a comeback with his first show since 2019 and allegations of sexual misconduct. But this time, there was no after-party.
content: LOS ANGELES — Dozens of showgoers approached security personnel and black-clad staff with the same question: Would there be an after-party? But the answer, for one of the first times at a major Alexander Wang fashion show, was a resounding no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: An Architect and Decorator Who Thinks of His Books as Windows Into Worlds
description: At home in Ibiza, Daniel Romualdez absorbs all kinds of ideas and images and then lets them marinate.
content: Books have always been an important part of my life. When I was growing up in the Philippines, my mom had a small room filled with books and magazines; it was dark and cool, which is a treat in a tropical climate, and I’d get lost in there. During boarding school in Washington, D.C., the highlight of my weekends was going to a bookshop in Georgetown. By the time I graduated, I’d filled three Billy Baldwin-style étagères. Years later, I’d buy books at the old Rizzoli on Fifth Avenue in New York and at Heywood Hill in London: ones on art and architecture, gardening and food, some fiction and some nonfiction, all linked by my interest in how people live their lives — in every sense. For me, as something of an outsider, books are windows into the worlds that I’m curious about. I’ve never thrown one out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Stanleyville’ Review: The Most Senseless Game
description: This absurdist farce brings together a cast of odd ducks to compete for an S.U.V.
content: The absurdist farce “Stanleyville” begins with the prim-and-proper pink-coated Maria (Susanne Wuest) witnessing a bird fly into an office window. It’s a random event, but one that shakes her. Life, even for a bird, is full of meaningless humiliations. The film attempts to recreate this initial image of futility with human characters, but the movie makes less of an impression than the bird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: MoneyGram Sued for Allegedly Delaying Transfers and Withholding Refunds
description: Customers sending remittances overseas were harmed by delays and other violations, according to a lawsuit from the federal consumer bureau and the New York attorney general.
content: The international money transfer company MoneyGram harmed customers by delaying transfers and failing to properly investigate and fix transfer errors, according to a lawsuit filed Thursday by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and New York’s attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson
title: Rirkrit Tiravanija’s Pad Thai Is Both a Meal and an Artwork
description: The artist uses food as a medium and as a means of connection — including with his students.
content: I don’t really think of what I do as an artistic practice. There’re no boundaries or limits. All the ways I fill a day — even if I’m doing nothing at all — are one and the same. I don’t have a studio. I don’t wake up and go to a place where I sit down and make things. I just do what I need or want to do, and throughout that process, I think about various possible works. Everything informs everything else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron and Le Pen Trade Punches in Pivotal Debate on France’s Future
description: He attacked the far-right leader as a Putin stooge. She hit back at him as the president of division and contempt.
content: PARIS — In a bruising debate ahead of the vote on Sunday in the French presidential election, President Emmanuel Macron accused his far-right challenger, Marine Le Pen, of being in the pocket of Russia, and she countered with a withering attack on the “unbearable injustice” of Mr. Macron’s economic measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Duke’ Review: Suspect’s 61
description: This film from the director Roger Michell has a compelling art-thief protagonist, but is weighed down by soggy family drama.
content: A Robin Hood figure polarizes England in “The Duke,” an ambling, sentimental account of the 1961 heist of Francisco de Goya’s portrait of the Duke of Wellington from the National Gallery in London. The police assume that the thief is a criminal mastermind. The public imagines the villain from Dr. No (1963), who displayed the purloined painting in his lair. But the man standing trial is a more unusual suspect: a 61-year-old cabdriver, Kempton Bunton (Jim Broadbent), who claims that he swiped the art over frustration that the British government would rather spend money lionizing the dead than lifting up its working class. His ransom notes demand a charitable donation. (The real painting was returned in 1965; Bunton turned himself in.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Creative Juices
description: How do you express creativity?
content: Are you a creative person? Where do your ideas come from? How do you express your creativity? Do you have creative friends or family members? What creative works of art or pop culture spur your imagination?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dickson
title: With an Opera of His Own, William Kentridge Looks Into the Future
description: The South African artist developed a piece about how difficult it is to see around the next corner. Ironically, the work anticipated the uncertainties of pandemic life.
content: LONDON — Billions of us have spent the past two or so years trying to divine the future. Will I get Covid-19? How bad will it be? When will the coronavirus pandemic end? Will it ever end? Reliable answers have been scant; even if we’ve been cushioned from the worst effects, many people have been camping in a sort of existential waiting room, living in near-permanent uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karrie Jacobs
title: Why Libraries May Never Stop Being People Places
description: Redesigned buildings with outdoor gathering areas were underway before Covid hit. Now, they look like 20/20 foresight.
content: As the first winter of the pandemic drew to a close, someone in my Twitter feed enthused about an app called Libby that made it especially easy to borrow and read library books. I downloaded it, input my New York Public Library card number and proceeded to binge. I devoured everything by and about Isaac Babel, who wrote stories based on his life in early-20th-century Odessa, and all of Mick Herron’s Slough House books, about a group of sad, incompetent British spies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Nets May Be in Trouble. But They Still Have Kevin Durant.
description: The brilliant Durant who so often appears in critical moments? He’s been missing in the playoffs against the Celtics. “I just got to go out there and play,” he said.
content: BOSTON — Kevin Durant had no room. He admitted as much. Whenever he had the ball against the Celtics on Wednesday night, and even when he did not, defenders were crowding his space, shadowing him, draping themselves all over him like Saran wrap. They were on the perimeter, and in the paint, and at the elbow. How was it possible that only five of them were on the court at once?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: With Corsican Reds, a Case Study of Identity
description: What is the source of the distinctiveness in these wines? The grapes? The soil and climate? Or maybe the people and culture? In a word, terroir.
content: Wine assessment is often depicted as dispassionate evaluation in which wines are judged solely on their sensory characteristics, free of bias or commercial involvement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Calling Off Steel Plant Assault, Putin Prematurely Claims Victory in Mariupol
description: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed victory in Mariupol on Thursday despite persistent fighting there, publicly calling off an assault on the final Ukrainian stronghold in the devastated city in a stark display of the Kremlin’s desire to present a success to the Russian public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: For Radha Blank, a Park Bench Can Be the Best Seat in the House
description: The writer and filmmaker has learned to create by closely observing the world around her.
content: I moved to Harlem from Brooklyn with my mother when I was about 15; since then, the neighborhood has influenced me as a New Yorker, a storyteller and an artist. There’s living history here — the immigrant communities, ethnic groups, working-class folks and struggling artists make the culture in New York, and Harlem’s representative of that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Jan Hoffman
title: Routine Childhood Vaccinations in the U.S. Slipped During the Pandemic
description: Nationwide, the number of kindergartners with the required shots fell below the target for broad immunity, raising fears of outbreaks of measles and other illnesses.
content: Kindergartners in the United States fell behind on routine childhood vaccinations during the pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Thursday, a slide that experts attributed to skipped checkups and to a groundswell of resistance to Covid-19 shots spilling into unease about other vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘For Colored Girls’ Returns, Leading With Joy
description: Camille A. Brown’s revival of Ntozake Shange’s 1976 Broadway landmark brings exuberant life to a play that celebrates Black women’s solidarity in the face of pain.
content: Don’t be fooled by the scaffolding that wraps around the exterior of the Booth Theater, doing its dour best to look uninviting. Inside is a Broadway homecoming celebration that you will not want to miss: the triumphant return of Ntozake Shange’s “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow Is Enuf” to the stage where it was a hit in 1976.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Some People Turn Suffering Into Wisdom
description: They have the ability to reconsider everything they thought they knew.
content: Barbara Lazear Ascher’s husband gave her the news in the most straightforward way. “Looks like pancreatic cancer,” he told her matter-of-factly after the test results came back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald
title: See Mariupol’s Azovstal steel-mill fortress in peacetime, and then after nearly two months of war.
description: Before-and-after images show the scale of destruction that the Ukrainian port city has suffered after nearly two months of near constant bombardment by Russian artillery, mortars and airstrikes.
content: In late January, while in Mariupol reporting on how Ukrainian forces were bracing for a Russian invasion, a New York Times video team captured drone footage over the Azovstal Iron and Steel works plant, an engine of industry for the southern port city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: Tschabalala Self Sought a Painting Style That Was Wholly Unique
description: The artist sews directly onto canvases, sometimes using fabric her mother collected.
content: I always wanted to make work that had mystery to it. Like, if you were to look at it, you wouldn’t quite understand how it was made. As a painter, I hoped to be able to add something to the larger lexicon and say, “OK, I contributed a new way of making a painting.” Maybe it’s an ego thing, but I felt like I had to create some kind of formal aspect that was entirely unique to me and my studio practice so that someone could look at a piece and say, “Oh, that’s a Tschabalala painting.” When I was in grad school at Yale, I focused primarily on printmaking. And I’d gotten a lot of success out of that, but there were also limitations. That’s how I started sewing fabric directly onto the canvas. It has a lot of the same qualities as printmaking: embedded color, texture and design.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: From ‘Kaikeyi’ to Cartography, Audiobooks That Make You Question What You Know
description: Fantastical maps, timeless tales and a new twist on an ancient Hindu classic.
content: At some point a very long time ago, our ancestors found that they had the free time and intellectual capacity to tell one another stories. Those stories may have begun as simple entertainment, or attempts to explain the unexplainable, but over time they gained complexity. Soon, our stories started folding back on themselves, re-examining the spoken — or written — words that came before to find even further meanings. The good news is that in the tens of thousands of years since those first narratives, we haven’t yet stopped coming up with new ones, retracing old ones and striving to better understand the world through them. These three new audiobooks show just how far we’ve come in reaching past our external reality within our minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: Haegue Yang’s Radical Art of Obscure Delights
description: A surprise stay in her native South Korea led the artist, whose work will appear in Berlin this month, to study the paper-cutting rituals of shamans.
content: SEOUL — When the South Korean artist Haegue Yang went to see one of her sculptures while it was installed outdoors last year, she was required to strap on a bulletproof vest and a helmet, pass through military checkpoints and leave her phone behind. Finally, just a mile south of North Korea’s border in the Korean Demilitarized Zone, she reached her piece, a roughly five-foot-tall block of gray soapstone with a translucent bird perched atop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Sexual Drive’ Review: Best Served Hot and Heavy
description: Natto, mapo tofu and fatty ramen become objects of titillation in this intriguing Japanese triptych that centers on sex without ever depicting it.
content: A sexless husband queries his wife’s lover over a package of natto. A nervous driver on her way to buy mapo sauce finds her panic attack transform into a paroxysm of passion when she collides with an old schoolmate. And a married man obeys enigmatic instructions to rescue his paramour after she’s kidnapped from a ramen shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The YouTube Rabbit Hole Is Nuanced
description: It’s unlikely that you’ll be watching kitten videos one day and believing in QAnon the next.
content: Perhaps you have an image in your mind of people who get brainwashed by YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: Reading Between the Design Lines
description: New books unearth details about houses in Queens, obsolete inventions, Japanese textiles and a pioneering architect.
content: For more than a decade, the architect Rafael Herrin-Ferri has methodically combed Queens neighborhoods, fascinated by the range of what he describes as “levels of exhibitionism” in residences equipped with asymmetrical roof spikes and crimson-speckled facades. His book All the Queens Houses: An Architectural Portrait of New York’s Largest and Most Diverse Borough (Jovis, $22.99, 272 pp.) documents how Queens subdivision dwellers vie for attention with aqua awnings, watermelon stucco pigments and driveways patterned in sine waves. Simulated cracks slash across brickwork on townhouse chimney stacks, and mansards seem to be melting. He gently chides a “dead cat” crevice between homes that would be “impossible to clean” and a balcony on spindly stilts that has “the smooth surfaces and floating quality of a hydraulic car lift.” But he largely avoids judgment while devising formal titles for dwellings like Pixel Ghost, Cerulean Icebox, Minoan Makeover and Samurai Helmet House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jameson Montgomery
title: Christopher John Rogers Takes Mini Vacations in Fort Greene Park
description: The fashion designer has explored silhouettes informed by Brooklyn’s carryout containers and garbage bags.
content: I’ve lived in Brooklyn since I moved to New York in 2016, right after I graduated from the Savannah College of Art and Design [in Georgia]. I used to be in the Bed-Stuy area, and I’d visit Fort Greene Park quite often. The greenery is so different from that in Bushwick, where I live now. Sometimes, I’m with my boyfriend, or old co-workers or current ones, or friends I met along the way. Going to the park is a little vacation, a chance to hang out and clear my head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 27, 2022
description: Do Americans think we have a free speech problem?
content: This graph about freedom of speech was produced by The New York Times based on a national poll conducted from Feb. 9 to 22, 2022, by Siena College. The poll included 1,507 U.S. residents 18 or older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney to Lose Special Tax Status in Florida Amid ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Clash
description: Lawmakers in the state voted to revoke the company’s special designation after a dispute with Gov. Ron DeSantis over a new education law.
content: Disney employs 38 lobbyists in Florida’s capital. Each election cycle, the company gives generous campaign contributions to Florida candidates on both sides of the political aisle. Its theme park megaresort near Orlando attracts around 50 million visitors a year, powering a Central Florida tourism economy that annually generates more than $5 billion in local and state tax revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The U.S. is extending a vaccine rule for international travelers at its land borders.
description: Unlike air travelers entering the United States, land and ferry travelers will still not have to show a recent negative coronavirus test to cross the border.
content: International travelers arriving at land ports of entry or ferry terminals in the United States must continue to show proof of full vaccination against the coronavirus, the Department of Homeland Security said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Word of the Day: pro forma

content: The term pro forma has appeared in 17 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 2 in “Dua Lipa Brings Her Lockdown Anthems to the Arena” by Jon Caramanica:

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: How Katerina Tannenbaum Dances Her Way Out of Her Head
description: When feeling overwhelmed, the “And Just Like That…” actor rents a studio and finds freedom in movement.
content: I grew up dancing and doing musical theater in Portland, Ore. I was obsessed with Bob Fosse, Broadway and New York — I moved to the city when I was 18, initially to go to dance school, though I didn’t enroll because I wanted to study theater instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Donald Trump Jr. Plans to Meet With Jan. 6 Committee
description: The former president’s eldest son, who encouraged White House officials to pursue “multiple paths” to overturn his father’s election loss, is said to have agreed to appear voluntarily.
content: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr., former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest son, has agreed to meet soon with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, according to a person familiar with matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Pissarro Seized by Nazis to Be Sold at Auction After Families Settle
description: The painting, which had been left behind by a Jewish couple who left Germany as Hitler rose to power, is to be sold in May at Christie’s.
content: A Pissarro painting that was at the center of a dispute between the heirs of a Jewish couple whose art collection was seized by the Nazis before World War II and a Jewish family who bought it in 1994 will be sold at auction next month after the two sides reached agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Long Can I Avoid Socializing With My Neighbors?
description: A reader wants to keep a friendly distance from the people next door after seeing what one of them has been posting on Facebook.
content: My husband and I moved to a new city recently. Our next-door neighbors introduced themselves right away, and they were very friendly to us. We hung out a few times. They were fun! Then I added one of them as a friend on Facebook and saw that they spread misinformation about the Covid vaccine, various political figures and people with substance abuse issues. Oof! My husband and I decided we will be polite when we see them, but we won’t drink beers or watch movies with them anymore. Still, they keep inviting us to hang out. I feel awkward refusing their invitations while seeing them across the yard. Should I just explain to them why we don’t want to be friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Keri Blakinger
title: How a Crime-Fighting Institution Took a Partisan Turn
description: Crime Stoppers of Houston built its reputation on a successful tip line. Then it decided to take on Democratic judges.
content: HOUSTON — “Anyone with information is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 713-222-TIPS.” That message, along with the promise of a reward, has appeared for decades at the end of news reports about shootings, stabbings or criminal mayhem in the nation’s fourth-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Chiwetel Ejiofor Was Asked to Play a Space Alien. He Knew What to Do.
description: For the Showtime series “The Man Who Fell to Earth,” the actor mined his own experience to find a voice for a being who must learn to be human.
content: When weighing whether to tackle a role, Chiwetel Ejiofor considers just how much the thought of it rattles him. He welcomes the rattling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Can Robots Save Nursing Homes?
description: The pandemic has given a new urgency to the development of robots and ‘virtual assisted living’ that can help care for aging adults, physically and emotionally.
content: Arshia Khan asked a group of older adults in Minnesota what they would like in a nursing home, and their answer surprised her. They wanted standup comedy, but not just any comedy: They wanted off-color jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Art and Mementos Go Up for Auction
description: More than 150 items that belonged to the Supreme Court justice, who died in 2020, will be sold. Proceeds will benefit the Washington National Opera, which she frequently attended.
content: More than 150 personal items and works of art that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg kept in her Washington residence and Supreme Court chambers are up for auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Daryle Lamonica, Hard-Throwing Quarterback, Is Dead at 80
description: Known as the Mad Bomber for his powerful arm, he led the Oakland Raiders to the Super Bowl and was among pro football’s top passers in the late 1960s and early ’70s.
content: Daryle Lamonica, the quarterback known as the Mad Bomber for his powerful arm, which led the Oakland Raiders to a berth in Super Bowl II, died on Thursday at his home in Fresno, Calif. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Peter Swales, Who Startled Freud Scholarship, Dies at 73
description: He was not a traditional academic, but his eyebrow-raising research challenged received wisdom on Sigmund Freud.
content: Peter Swales, a self-taught scholar who shook up the cloistered world of Freudian studies with brash research and theories that painted Sigmund Freud’s personal life as something less than exemplary and cast aspersions on some of his psychotherapy, died on Friday at his home near Izmir, Turkey. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Benjamin Mullin
title: CNN+ Streaming Service Will Shut Down Weeks After Its Start
description: A major investment by CNN, which poached big-name anchors and threw a splashy launch party, ends abruptly at the hands of a new corporate leadership team.
content: At sunset on the last Monday of March, CNN stars gathered for a gala on the 101st floor of a Midtown Manhattan skyscraper to celebrate the launch of CNN+, the streaming service that was supposed to take the network into the digital future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Bad Behavior Drove a Referee Shortage. Covid Made It Worse.
description: For years, unruly parents have turned youth sporting events into a toxic environment. The cancellation of games and entire seasons over the last two years hastened an exodus of referees.
content: The 13-year-old soccer players in Cincinnati had been pulling at their opponents’ jerseys all game. Rhiana Garcia raised her flag again and again, signaling fouls. But a coach took issue with her officiating that October night in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow and Sasha Weiss
title: Do You Skip Intro?
description: Wesley Morris and Hanif Abdurraqib consider what’s lost when you breeze past the TV theme song.
content: Wesley worries the “skip intro” button is killing the TV theme song. When we skip, we’re denying “the possibility of having this connection with a show that becomes bigger and more meaningful than the show itself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Braces for Potential French Election Shockwave
description: An upset victory by the right-wing nationalist Marine Le Pen in the presidential election on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s foreign policy.
content: WASHINGTON — U.S. officials are anxiously watching the French presidential election, aware that the outcome of the vote on Sunday could scramble President Biden’s relations with Europe and reveal dangerous fissures in Western democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Wogan
title: In a Paris Garden, Daniel Roseberry Sketches in Peace
description: At the Tuileries, the Schiaparelli artistic director reconnects with his creative innocence.
content: My entire life in Paris can be summed up in three locations: my apartment, the Schiaparelli studio in the Place Vendôme and the Tuileries Garden, which is halfway between the two. I walk to work every day, and I like to stop here and sketch, sitting next to a female figure made of stone. It’s a sacred time and space for me because once I arrive at work, it’s a nonstop schedule of meetings, interviews and phone calls. I learned during the pandemic how much I enjoy the feeling of working when no one else is, that freedom you feel early in the morning or late at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Johnny Depp v. Amber Heard: What We Know
description: Mr. Depp has sued Ms. Heard, his ex-wife, on grounds that she defamed him in an op-ed she wrote for The Washington Post.
content: The defamation trial in Virginia between the actors Johnny Depp and Amber Heard has become a fierce battleground over the truth about their relationship, with both sides accusing the other of repeated domestic abuse in what was an unquestionably tumultuous marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent’ Review: Being Nicolas Cage
description: Nicolas Cage plays Nick Cage — maybe, kind of, not really — in a comically romantic, buddy-movie thriller that is also an ode to him in all his Caginess.
content: Those eyes, that hair, those choppers and, oh, that purring, whining adenoidal voice, which can change pitch and intensity midsentence (midword!) and often seems a bit stuffed up. To know or, anyway, to watch Nicolas Cage is to love him and sometimes also be confused by him (which is A-OK). He can be a joy and a conundrum, startling and remarkable, but also fantastically, gloriously untethered. Who is this? you sometimes wonder, agog. What is this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Treffinger
title: When It Comes to Cameras and Wallpaper, Bold Is Better
description: Advice for buying a home security system, reviving vintage pieces, finding furniture that supports a restless work style and sprucing up your walls.
content: Can you recommend a security camera for outside my house that is discreet and looks really modern?

author: By James Barron
title: Is New York Headed for a Higher Covid Risk Level?
description: The city could be close to raising its risk level, and the state could be seeing a new spike in coronavirus cases.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at why New York City may raise its Covid-19 risk level soon. We’ll also look at why only a fraction of the aid promised by government officials has reached survivors of a fire in a Bronx high-rise in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Archie Comics Brings a Queer Character to Riverdale
description: The new character, Eliza Han, who is biracial, will serve as a rival to Reggie for the affections of Harper Lodge. Drama!
content: The world of Riverdale, the comic book home of the redheaded Archie Andrews and friends, will expand in June with the introduction of Eliza Han.

author: By M.H. Miller
title: Behind the Scenes: Capturing a Day in the Creative Life
description: How T Magazine’s 2022 Culture issue, on stands April 24, came together.
content: For its 2022 Culture issue, “The Artist’s Way,” T photographed and interviewed 34 artists from various disciplines to provide a glimpse into how creative people live and work. Rather than focus on grand gestures, the idea was to instead highlight the seemingly mundane activities that some of our greatest artists either incorporate into their creative processes — or pursue in order to let their minds empty and drift. “I told our photographers that this issue is about private, internal moments,” says Nadia Vellam, T’s photography and video director. “I wanted the portraits to be cinematic and voyeuristic, and to focus on someone in a moment of personal expression or contemplation.” Collectively, the images provide windows into the subjects’ daily routines: the choreographer Raja Feather Kelly waiting for the F train, the conceptual artist Rirkrit Tiravanija cooking pad Thai and the actor Ethan Hawke walking his dogs (“They were incredibly well behaved,” Vellam notes).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: Why Faith Ringgold Makes Sure Her Pieces Bear Her Signature
description: At 91, the artist is reflecting on her oeuvre.
content: I started printmaking when I was in high school, and it’s remained a part of my process ever since. It’s always been very challenging, but I’ve never limited myself to one technique. Over the years, I’ve made work by etching, woodblock, lithography and silk-screen. Printmaking is a labor-intensive and technical process, but it’s also collaborative. Early on, I collaborated with my mother, Willi Posey Jones, who was a fashion designer, to create quilts and soft sculptures. In the 1980s, I worked with the master printmaker Bob Blackburn on a series of abstractions, which I made into quilts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Johnny Depp Confronted With Texts and Audio at Libel Trial
description: Mr. Depp was questioned on the stand by lawyers for his ex-wife Amber Heard, whom he is suing for defamation.
content: Lawyers for Amber Heard worked on Thursday to point out inconsistencies in Johnny Depp’s testimony in the defamation trial between the formerly married actors, presenting text messages sent by Mr. Depp and audio recordings of the couple’s arguments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Green Is Your Metropolis?
description: Allowing more density would make America better.
content: Normally, a special election for California’s State Assembly wouldn’t have much national significance — especially not an election in San Francisco, a liberal, Democratic city that’s the opposite of a swing district.

title: ‘Great Comet’ Producer Hasn’t Paid Royalties, Composer Says

title: Allergy Season Is About to Get Worse. Here’s How to Prepare.
description: If you act quickly, there are a few practical steps you can take to manage symptoms, reduce allergens in your home and get long-term relief.
content: Springtime comes with an uptick in stuffy noses and scratchy throats, and for many it has nothing to do with Covid-19. There are 19.2 million adults and 5.2 million children in the United States who suffer from seasonal allergies, also called hay fever, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Late Night Celebrates 4/20
description: “Time for all you doobie-lovin’ potheads to get up to your usual smoky high jinks: folding laundry and hoping half a gummy will help you fall asleep,” Stephen Colbert joked.

title: Fed Chair Powell Calls a Faster Pace of Rate Increases ‘Appropriate’

title: Ex-Honduran President Extradited to United States to Face Drug Charges
description: Juan Orlando Hernández, who stepped down in January, was flown to New York on Thursday after failed attempts to block the U.S. government’s extradition request.
content: The former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández was extradited to the United States on Thursday, where he will face charges in a New York court accusing him of trafficking drugs for decades to further his political career.

author: By Brett Berk
title: Lotus Adds an S.U.V., With Eyes on Mainstream Appeal

content: It is not a lithe, analog sports car or racer, powered by gasoline — making it an outlier among nearly all the 131 Lotus vehicles that preceded it.

author: By Marley Marius
title: Chika Has Never Lost Sight of Her Dream
description: Even when the rapper is taking a break from work, she has the urge to get up in the middle of the night and record in her home studio.
content: I get the most work done at night. I like when it’s light out and the world’s up, but when it’s quiet or when everybody’s asleep, I can go uninterrupted. The years that my peers were in college, making friends and forming bonds, I was working toward a dream. In lockdown, when everyone experienced what it was like to basically do everything by yourself, from the internet, at home — I’ve been doing that since I was a kid. My EPs “Industry Games” (2020) and “Once Upon a Time” (2021) were the culmination of all my dreams coming true. When I put “Industry Games” out, my team and I were popping bottles and celebrating. Three days later, the world shut down. So I’ve gotten to experience success but also feel as though I’ve lost it.

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Parents Aren’t the Only Ones With Rights
description: We all have a stake in public schools. You wouldn’t know it from the fights in Florida and elsewhere.
content: Enough about “parental rights.” I want to talk about nonparental rights.

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: Kae Tempest’s Music Defies Boundaries. A New LP Demolishes Even More.
description: The prolific British poet and musician’s fourth album, “The Line Is a Curve,” is personal in new ways.
content: LONDON — “I’m just going to go into it, and I’ll see you on the other side,” Kae Tempest told the crowd at an intimate concert earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: N.Y. House Districts Illegally Favor Democrats, Appeals Court Rules
description: A divided five-judge panel found that Democrats engaged in gerrymandering in creating new district maps. The case is expected to head to New York’s highest court.
content: A New York appeals court ruled on Thursday that new congressional districts drawn by Democrats violated the state’s ban on partisan gerrymandering, partially upholding a lower-court ruling that would block the state from using the lines in this year’s critical midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: Putin’s Defensive Speech
description: The Russian leader claimed victory in Mariupol, despite Ukrainian resistance.
content: President Vladimir Putin of Russia said it was “impractical” for Russian forces to attack the steel factory in Mariupol where Ukrainian forces and roughly 1,000 civilians are stuck in bunkers. Instead, Putin ordered a complete blockade.
